Chrome ToDo

A simple packaged Chrome ToDo app and a tutorial on how to get started...

Download .zip Download .tar.gz View on GitHub

Step 5 - Adding JavaScript Functionality

Jun 2, 2015 â€¢ Shahzeb Ihsan

Previous Step: Creating the HTML View

In folder "js", create a file called "application.js" and add the js path to the end of your HTML body (window.html)...

<html>
    <head>
        <meta charset="utf-8">
        <title>Chrome ToDo</title>
    </head>

    <body>
        <input id="text" placeholder="Type something here...">
        <button id="enter">Enter</button>
        <textarea id="output" rows="13" cols="25" readonly>Data log...</textarea>

        <script src="js/application.js"></script>
    </body>
</html>

For the JavaScript functionality, all we are going to do right now is to add anything typed in the input to the textarea when the button is pressed.

/**
 * Called on the "onload" event, sets event handlers for various elements.
 */
onload = function() {
    document.getElementById('enter').onclick = function() {
        // When the "Enter" button is pressed, text is read from the input
        // and updated in the textarea
        var txt = document.getElementById('output').value + '\r\n';
        txt += document.getElementById('text').value;
        document.getElementById('output').value = txt;
    };
};

Now, go to chrome://extensions and reload your app and launch your application.

There you go, a fully functional, albeit useless, Chrome app

Now we'll add some basic CSS in the next step and that will wrap up the tutorial.

You can checkout the "sandbox" branch at the following commit (refer to this post if you need a quick reference to Git commands for doing this):

git checkout c0c517a67b40445a3c0970725ef159db1fd4ff7c
